newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AUSTRALIA'S QNI SEES COBALT PRICE DOWN 18 PCT.
newsitem.headline: AUSTRALIA'S QNI SEES COBALT PRICE DOWN 18 PCT.

text.p: Cobalt prices are set to decline by about 18 percent in the next six months, nickel and cobalt producer QNI Ltd said on Tuesday.

Current cobalt prices of around US$22 a pound should fall to about US$18 a pound by the end of June as more metal hits the market, QNI's chief financial officer, Christopher Foll told Reuters from Brisbane.

"We have an internal opinion the price will drop to US$18 by the end of the year (financial year ending June 30, 1997)," he said. "Probably in the next couple of years drop cobalt will drop to the US$12.00 to US$15.00 mark."
Some of the additional supplies of cobalt will come from producers in the African copper belt, whose production is being enhanced by outside companies, such as Belgium' Union Miniere SA, Foll said.
"If the Africans get their act together they can produce a lot of cobalt for the market," he said.
Sales of the metal from U.S. defence stockpile also was "keeping a cap on the market," he said.
Production of cobalt as a by-product of copper also was rising, he said.
Cobalt prices have already slipped in some markets, metals traders said.

Some fixed-price business for 1997 has been concluded at around US$19 a pound, for 99.3 percent cobalt produced in Russia, while 99.8 percent material fetched between US$20 and US$21 a pound, stockbroker JB Were and Son said in its latest commodity report.
